channel.title: Stories from theverge.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best theverge.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: Magic Keyboard For The iPad Pro Review: The Best Way To Turn An iPad Into A Laptop
item.description: It's what we've all been asking for — for better or worse.

item.title: The New iPhone SE Is A Shockingly Good Value
item.description: The most important thing to know about the SE's value proposition is simply that it has the A13 Bionic processor, which is bar-none the fastest processor you can get on any smartphone at any price, full stop.
item.kicker: GOOD THINGS COME IN SMALL PACKAGES

item.title: Even 'Small' Phones Are Big Now
item.description: Apple's new iPhone SE 2 is dramatically larger than the prior SE and signifies the end of the line for small smartphones.

item.title: Want Wheels For Your Mac Pro? That Will Be $699
item.description: Too expensive? Never fear, you can also get the stationary Mac Pro Feet Kit for… $299.

item.title: PokÃ©mon Go Adds Remote Raids So You Don't Have To Go Outside
item.description: Niantic is adding a new item called a Remote Raid Pass to PokÃ©mon Go, letting you play raids that appear on the app's map or "Nearby" page without having to go to the physical location.

item.title: Here's Apple's New $399 iPhone SE
item.description: It has a 4.7-inch screen and a home button with Touch ID. It's available for preorder starting on April 17th, and it'll ship on April 24th.
item.kicker: THE BEZELS ARE BACK IN TOWN

item.title: How Medium Became The Best And Worst Place For Coronavirus News
item.description: The platform empowers voices — and misinformation.
item.kicker: THE, UH, MEDIUM IS THE MESSAGE

item.title: Unemployment Checks Are Being Held Up By A Coding Language Almost Nobody Knows
item.description: States have been starved of modernization funding for years
item.kicker: TIME TO CALL THE COBOL GUY

item.title: Amazon Fires Two Tech Workers After They Publicly Criticized Warehouse Conditions
item.description: Amazon has fired two employees who criticized safety and working conditions at its warehouses during the COVID-19 pandemic Emily Cunningham and Maren Costa were both fired on Friday after they tweeted criticism of the company.

item.title: Apple And Google Are Building A Coronavirus Tracking System Into iOs And Android
item.description: Google and Apple are introducing an API to allow Bluetooth LE-based coronavirus exposure contact tracing through official public health authority apps and later as a lower-level feature of iOS and Android. The system could help warn users if they were around someone diagnosed with COVID-19.

item.title: The Boeing 737 Max's Big Problem? Its Computers Have The Processing Power Of A Super Nintendo
item.description: While Boeing has received plenty of scrutiny for its bad code, it's the Max's computing power — or lack thereof — that has kept it on the ground since then.

item.title: The Hollywood Job
item.description: eBay. HP. Governor of California (well, almost). Quibi? Meg Whitman's last act is her biggest bet yet.

item.title: What Is Twitch, Anyway?
item.description: Twitch is more than a website; it's chat, audiences, streamers and community itself. (It's also the tech that makes everything work.)

item.title: In Dr. Fauci We Stan: How The Coronavirus Leader Became A Beloved Meme
item.description: Dr. Fauci stans have created Facebook fan clubs, TikTok videos, donuts, and even prayer candles in celebration of the scientist leading the Trump White House's novel coronavirus response.

item.title: Nikon Is Offering Free Online Photography Classes For All Of April
item.description: Now through April 30th, all 10 classes available at the Nikon School can be streamed for free. The classes are normally priced anywhere between $15 to $50 each.

item.title: Saying 'I Do' Over Zoom
item.description: While some couples are canceling their weddings due to COVID-19, others are live-streaming their ceremonies on Zoom. Welcome to the era of the digital wedding.
item.kicker: THE RECEPTION IS A DIGITAL GET-DOWN

item.title: Sprint Is Dead. Long Live Sprint
item.description: Farewell to the carrier that coulda been a contender.

item.title: How Skype Is Missing Out To Zoom During The Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: If the coronavirus pandemic had swept across the world in 2011, everyone would have been using Skype to connect over video and voice calls. Instead, rivals like Zoom and Houseparty are having a moment of huge growth in 2020 thanks to consumers looking for Skype alternatives.

item.title: 'Good Job!' Lets You Chaotically Smash Through Your Office Complex From Home
item.description: Nintendo's latest puzzle game for the Switch is set in a charming office environment inspired by safety signs. Players can solve puzzles with smart, slow solutions or smash their way to success with slapstick chaos.

item.title: The Worst Amazon Shipping Delays Could Still Be Ahead Of Us
item.description: COVID-19 cases are spiking nationally, workers are getting sick, and I already can't get groceries delivered in San Francisco. The delivery economy is vital, but it's under incredible strain. Will it break?

item.title: Relaxing Isolation Rules Won't Help The Economy, Say Economists
item.description: President Donald Trump has pushed to relax social distancing and shelter-in-place rules by Easter Sunday, April 12th, but economists say relaxing restrictions could make the economic damage even worse.

item.title: Living A Google-Free Life With A Huawei Phone
item.description: Huawei is about to announce its latest flagship phones, the P40 series, but they won't be able to run Google apps. Does that mean you shouldn't even consider it? We spent time with the Mate 30 Pro to find out.

item.title: Newly Approved Novel Coronavirus Test Gives Results In 45 Minutes
item.description: The test runs on the biotechnology company Cepheid's system. There are around 5,000 of the systems in hospitals in the US. The US needs to ramp up rapid testing to bring the COVID-19 outbreak under control.

item.title: Don't Bail Out The Cruise Industry
item.description: Trump said it's a "prime candidate," but there are plenty of reasons not to.

item.title: How To Boost Your Home's WiFi
item.description: If you're now working at home due to the COVID-19 outbreak, you may have a moment when you realize that your Wi-Fi just isn't cutting it anymore. Here are a few things you can do to get the most out of your bandwidth.

item.title: This YouTuber Has Opened 334 Doors And Counting
item.description: "I open doors" is a YouTube channel where every video is a brief clip of a person opening a door. They've uploaded nearly every day for a full year, opening more than 300 doors on video.

item.title: Co-Founder Therapy Teaches Tech Bros How To Be In Their Feelings
item.description: Tech leaders in Silicon Valley are turning to couples counseling to work out their differences. The trend has sparked a new wave of therapists focused specifically on co-founders.

item.title: Facebook's Misinformation Problem Goes Deeper Than You Think
item.description: Misinformation is part of Facebook's business model, says Nathalie MarÃ©chal, a senior policy analyst at New America's Open Technology Institute.

item.title: Apple Explains How Returns And Repairs Will Work While Its Retail Stores Are Closed
item.description: On March 14th, Apple announced that all Apple stores outside China are closed until March 27th, and the company has since posted an FAQ with information about updated return policies, how to retrieve repairs and more.

item.title: TikTok Guidelines Said Not To Promote Posts By 'Ugly' And Poor Users
item.description: Leaked TikTok moderation guidelines show the app prevented "ugly facial looks" and videos shot in "slums" or "dilapidated housing" from appearing in its For You section.

item.title: The NYC Subway's New Tap-To-Pay System Has A Hidden Cost — Rider Data
item.description: OMNY, the new tap-to-pay fare system for New York City's subway, is collecting significant amounts of information from users, including smartphone device identifiers and location. Privacy advocates are worried this could be used to map out riders' patterns of life in minute detail.

item.title: Contrary To Trump's Claim, Google Is Not Building A Nationwide Coronavirus Screening Website
item.description: Instead, Verily is building a triage website just for the Bay Area

item.title: Apple To Close US Retail Stores And All Others Outside China Until March 27th
item.description: The company's online store will remain operational.
item.kicker: THE FIRST SHUTDOWN FROM A MAJOR RETAILER

item.title: The Best Movies And TV Shows To Stream When You're Working From Home
item.description: In an effort to stop the spread of the novel coronavirus, lots of people are stuck working from home, which means you might be looking for a new show or movie to start streaming. Fortunately, we're here to help.

item.title: The Man Behind The Mustache
item.description: Guy "Dr Disrespect" Beahm opens up about his Twitch alter ego.

item.title: Disney Park Employees Panic As Parks Remain Open Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: All cast members are still working today in California and Florida.

item.title: Public Service Announcement: These Memes Are Now Canceled
item.description: From Captain Picard facepalming to Antonio Banderas touching his lips, these memes are now banned for public safety reasons.

item.title: How To Work From Home
item.description: If you're working from home due to the coronavirus or just have a new remote position, here's how to get in a routine and stay focused.

item.title: The Rise Of Impossibly Cute And Wholesome Games
item.description: From frog detectives to adventuring fruit, games are getting real cute.

item.title: Scientists Will Soon Be Able To Monitor Air Pollution Hourly From Space
item.description: NASA, South Korea and the European Space Agency are collaborating on a project to monitor air pollution from space, for the first time.

item.title: The Koenigsegg Gemera Is The World's Most Wickedly Weird Hybrid
item.description: Three electric motors, one combustion engine and 1,700 horsepower.

item.title: Will America Ever Get Urban Transit Right?
item.description: Electric skateboard maker Boosted has been near the brink for longer than most people have realized, and it finally went over earlier this week with massive layoffs.
item.kicker: THE FUTURE IS STILL A WAYS OFF

item.title: The Drone Boat Of 'Shipwreck Alley'
item.description: Meet BEN, the self-driving boat that's been tasked with helping lay bare the long-lost secrets of the lakebed.

item.title: This Kickstarter Backpack Has It All: Kevlar, Batteries And A Federal Investigation
item.description: The man behind iBackpack, an alleged crowdfunding scam, wants you to know he isn't a scammer. The Verge's Ashley Carman visited Doug Monahan in Galveston, Texas, to hear his side of the story.
item.kicker: NOT CRAZY, JUST A LITTLE UNWELL

item.title: Apple Pro Display XDR Review: Category Of One
item.description: Can Apple's newest display satisfy every kind of pro?

item.title: Just A Few Questions About This Gamer Bed
item.description: Japanese retailer Bauhutte sells a great deal of furniture aimed at "gamers," but few can top its one-stop shop for sleep and gaming. The "ultimate gaming bed" setup, which turns eight different products into a cocoon, costs roughly ¥113,250, or about $1,048 (snacks sold separately).
item.kicker: DOES IT MAKE ITS OWN MOUNTAIN DEW?

item.title: How To Make Your Own Hand Sanitizer
item.description: If you're traveling, or otherwise don't have access to soap and water, the next best way to avoid diseases like the coronavirus is a hand sanitizer.

item.title: The Verge Tech Survey 2020: How People Feel About Apple, Google, Facebook And More
item.description: Ahead of the election year, we polled Americans about which big tech companies (Apple, Google, Facebook, Netflix, Microsoft, Amazon, and more) are the most trusted with personal information — and which ones should be broken up.

item.title: Disney's Massive Media Empire Leads To A Bizarre Pixar And 'Simpsons' Team-Up
item.description: Pixar's new movie "Onward" will come with an original short attached to it, like all Pixar movies, but this one won't be a Pixar original: it's "The Simpsons."

item.title: Imagine A World Without YouTube
item.description: YouTube has helped elect politicians, create entire industries, and taught millions of people how to use eyeliner. It's not a stretch to say it shaped the internet as we know it. But what if YouTube had failed?
